trans-unit.source: Provides access to HTTP request values without triggering ASP.NET request validation.

When ASP.NET reads the values in HTTP request collections (such as the <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest.Form%2A>, <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest.QueryString%2A>, and <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest.Cookies%2A> collections), it performs *request validation*.
During request validation, ASP.NET examines the posted values and determines whether they contain markup, script, or reserved characters.
By default, if ASP.NET detects any of these types of input, it throws an <xref:System.Web.HttpRequestValidationException> exception.
This helps prevent malicious script injection attacks on your website.
However, in some cases, you might want to bypass ASP.NET request validation and allow values that contain markup, script, or reserved characters.

For example, if your application uses a rich-text editor that enables users to submit HTML markup as formatted content, you can use the members of the UnvalidatedRequestValues class to retrieve the rich-text request values without triggering the default ASP.NET request validation.
In your code, you access members of this class by using the <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest.Unvalidated%2A> property.
> [!IMPORTANT] > If you use this class, you must manually check the data for potential cross-site scripting attacks.
Gets the collection of cookies that the client sent, without triggering ASP.NET request validation.
> [!IMPORTANT] > If you use this property, you must manually check the data for potential cross-site scripting attacks.
